This is why repeatedly racing a horse during a small period of time increases the chance of injury, and also why a lot of successful racehorses are retired so early; the sooner they're retired, the less chance there is for cumulative stress to result in a broken leg. MMORPGs typically suffer from quite a few issues both in gameplay and in story. To start, the gameplay is extremely repetitive- most games have a 'rotation', where the player has a number of skills which they use in a specific order in most fights, with variations when one of their situational skills is needed. However, most of these skills are completely superfluous. Instead of giving us a small number of abilities that give us an edge in combat but aren't entirely necessary, which is often the norm in single-player games, MMORPGs make your standard attack almost useless. And to make it worse, instead of giving you a small number of useful skills for various situations, they instead give you forty skills that rely on cooldowns to remain useful, half of which are completely situational and will almost never be used outside of high-end content that many users choose not to enter due to the sheer stress and chaos required to get that many people into a group. Compare this to Overwatch, which gives your character a small number of skills that are all constantly used, including more situational ones like Torbjorn's turret.
There are MMORPGs which don't have this problem. Games with much smaller numbers of powers - like Guild Wars 2 - exist, and The Secret World gave heroes only eight powers at a time. The Secret World actually didn't give you a "basic attack" at all - EVERYTHING you did was a power, with some having basically no cooldown. You "cycled" your powers by building up points by using attacks which built up points, and then spent said points on various other powers. You set which powers you were using at any given time, and could use powers from up to two different weapons; depending on which weapons you were mixing, you could get different varieties of tank, healing, and DPS.
TSW wasn't a perfect system, but it kept things pretty simple in terms of powers used at any given time, and you didn't have a bunch of useless powers equipped - you'd only equip powers you actually had some use for.
Third, the story doesn't actually matter. Your character is only recognized for your feats in related quest chains, and even that is erased over time. The best example of this is World of Warcraft, which often has your character be the chosen one alongside the other million characters. You beat Deadmines before Cataclysm came out and killed Van Kleefe many times, but instead a group of NPCs created specifically for a cutscene about Van Kleefe's death get credit. And there's also the fact that 99% of the quests are filler. Kill x creatures then report back, grab an item and bring back, be a messenger for people standing two feet apart from each other. In single-player RPGs, the quests matter, and have a noticeable impact on the world, but MMORPGs don't do that, and any sense of uniqueness that your character would have had is erased by the fact that everyone else did it too.

IQ is a bell curve (hence the name of the book The Bell Curve); IQ is a relative measure of intelligence compared to the average.
The difference between white and black IQ is a standard deviation; this means that the most common white IQ is 100, while the most common black IQ is 85 (in the US, mind).

The further you go away from the peak average IQ for a group, the fewer people there are. Thus, about 84% of white people are smarter than 50% of black people; conversely, about 16% of black people are smarter than 50% of white people.
Thus, black people are less likely to be above average and more likely to be below average as compared to white people, in aggregate across the population.
This 1 SD gap, then, is actually quite large. And as IQ has an enormous influence on life outcomes, this gap is one of the largest factors in the black-white achievement gap in general in the United States.

This is just a blatant lie, I'm afraid.
First off, poor white communities do exist. In fact, there are more poor white people than there are poor black people in the US. If crime was caused by poverty, then we should expect poor white people to commit more crime than poor black people (as there are more poor white people). Instead, over 50% of homicides and robberies are committed by blacks, despite the fact that blacks constitute only about a third of the nation's poor. Blacks commit crimes at a higher rate than whites do, even after adjusting for SES. This is true of other groups as well - poor Asians, Hispanics, and Native Americans also commit crimes at a lower rate than poor blacks on a per-capita basis, and on an absolute basis as well.
It should also be noted that the very poorest places in the US are generally rural areas inhabited by poor rural whites and Native Americans, not poor urban areas. So it isn't just absolute poverty.
Secondly, the idea that "black communities are kept impoverished" is simply not true. It is one of those Big Lies which is primarily spread by (ironically) racists. The reality is that the poverty of black communities is largely self-reinforcing - better-off people leave poor black communities because they aren't desirable places to live or start a business, and if a place ceases to be undesirable to live in, it will attract more people and cease to be a poor black community. There are many black communities which aren't poor - most black people aren't poor, in fact.
But the places which are poor and overwhelmingly black aren't places that most people want to live due to the high crime rates. People talk about white flight, but it is really everyone flight - better off black people don't live there, either.
